description: Questions covering first-round draft pick contracts, team options, salary amounts, and rookie contract extensions

questions.question: What is the standard length of a Rookie Scale Contract for a first-round draft pick?
questions.explanation: Rookie Scale Contracts are 2 years guaranteed with 2 additional years as team options (3rd and 4th year options). This gives teams up to 4 years of team-controlled salary.

questions.question: By when must a team exercise the third-year option on a Rookie Scale Contract?
options: Before October 31 of the second year
Before the last day of the second year
By the trade deadline of the second year
Before October 31 of the first year
questions.explanation: Teams must exercise the third-year option by October 31 of the second year of the contract. This gives teams two full seasons to evaluate the player before deciding.

questions.question: What percentage range of the Rookie Scale amount can a first-round pick's salary be?
questions.explanation: First-round picks can sign for 80% to 120% of the applicable Rookie Scale amount. This gives some flexibility in negotiations while staying within defined parameters.

questions.question: If a team declines the fourth-year option on a Rookie Scale Contract, when does the player become a free agent?
options: At the end of the third season
At the end of the fourth season
After the All-Star break of the third year
questions.explanation: If the fourth-year option is declined, the player completes the third year and becomes a free agent at the end of that season. The team must decide on the fourth-year option by October 31 of the third year.

questions.question: Can a player on a Rookie Scale Contract be extended before completing their third season?
options: No, must complete the third season first
Yes, but only if they made an All-Star team
questions.explanation: A Rookie Scale player cannot sign an extension until after they complete their third season (if the team exercised the third-year option) or after the second season (if the third-year option was declined).

questions.question: What is the maximum percentage annual raise allowed in a Rookie Scale extension?
options: Varies based on team's cap situation
questions.explanation: Rookie Scale extensions are limited to 8% annual raises, regardless of whether the team has Bird rights. This is lower than the 10% raise available for non-rookie extensions with Bird rights.

questions.question: How is the salary for the #1 overall pick in the draft determined?
options: Fixed by a scale based on the salary cap
questions.explanation: The Rookie Scale sets specific salary amounts for each draft position based on a percentage of the salary cap. The #1 pick has the highest predetermined amount.

questions.question: What happens if a team fails to make a Qualifying Offer to a player whose fourth-year option was exercised?
options: The player becomes an Unrestricted Free Agent
The player becomes a Restricted Free Agent anyway
The team retains exclusive negotiating rights
The player must re-enter the draft
questions.explanation: If a team exercises the fourth-year option but fails to extend a Qualifying Offer after that season, the player becomes an Unrestricted Free Agent rather than a Restricted Free Agent.

questions.question: Can Rookie Scale Contracts include performance bonuses?
options: Yes, but limited to 15% of base salary
Only if approved by the league
questions.explanation: Rookie Scale Contracts cannot include performance bonuses. The salary is determined solely by the scale amount (within the 80-120% range) and cannot be enhanced with incentives.

questions.question: If a first-round pick is drafted by Team A but traded to Team B before signing, which team's Rookie Scale applies?
options: The player's choice of either team
questions.explanation: The draft pick slot determines the Rookie Scale amount regardless of which team signs the player. If traded, the acquiring team signs the player to the scale amount for that draft position.

questions.question: What is the annual percentage increase for each year of a Rookie Scale Contract?
questions.explanation: The Rookie Scale includes built-in raises of approximately 20% for the second year, then for the option years. The exact percentages are predetermined in the scale table.

questions.question: Can a team buy out a Rookie Scale Contract?
options: Yes, but only after the second year
No, these contracts cannot be bought out
questions.explanation: Rookie Scale Contracts cannot be bought out. The team's only options are to keep the player, trade them, or waive them (which would still count against the cap unless waived via the stretch provision).

questions.question: If the 15th pick in the draft signs for 120% of the Rookie Scale amount, what does the 16th pick's maximum possible salary become?
options: Must be less than the 15th pick
Can be higher than the 15th pick if at 120%
The same dollar amount as the 15th pick
questions.explanation: Each draft slot has its own scale amount. The 16th pick can still sign for up to 120% of their scale amount, which may result in overlap where a lower pick makes similar money if signed at maximum.

questions.question: By when must a team exercise the fourth-year option on a Rookie Scale Contract?
options: Before October 31 of the third year
Before the trade deadline of the third year
Before the end of the third year season
By July 1 following the third year
questions.explanation: Like the third-year option, the fourth-year option must be exercised by October 31, but of the third year. This gives teams three seasons to evaluate before committing to year four.

questions.question: What is the minimum salary a first-round pick can sign for as a percentage of their Rookie Scale amount?
questions.explanation: The minimum is 80% of the Rookie Scale amount. In practice, almost all first-round picks sign for at least 100% or close to 120%, but 80% is the floor.

questions.question: If both the third and fourth-year options are exercised, when is the earliest a Rookie Scale player can sign an extension?
options: After the All-Star break of the third year
Immediately after the fourth-year option is exercised
questions.explanation: A player must complete their third season before they are eligible to sign a Rookie Scale extension. This typically happens in the summer between years three and four.

questions.question: Can a team convert a Rookie Scale Contract to a Two-Way Contract?
options: No, these are separate contract types
questions.explanation: Rookie Scale Contracts and Two-Way Contracts are distinct contract types with different rules. A first-round pick signs a Rookie Scale Contract and it cannot be converted to a Two-Way.

questions.question: What percentage of the salary cap does the #1 overall pick's first-year salary typically represent?
questions.explanation: The #1 pick's first-year salary is approximately 5-7% of the salary cap, depending on the specific cap amount. This percentage is defined in the Rookie Scale table.

questions.question: If a Rookie Scale player is waived and claimed by another team, what happens to the team options?
options: The claiming team inherits the same options
The options are voided and must be renegotiated
The player immediately becomes a free agent
questions.explanation: When a Rookie Scale player is claimed off waivers, the claiming team inherits the exact same contract terms, including the team option years and deadlines.

questions.question: What is the maximum length of a Rookie Scale extension?
questions.explanation: A Rookie Scale extension can be for up to 4 years beyond the current contract. Combined with the option years, this means a player could be under team control for up to 8 years total.

questions.question: Does the Rookie Scale apply to second-round draft picks?
options: Yes, but at 50% of first-round amounts
Only if they're selected in the top 45
questions.explanation: The Rookie Scale only applies to first-round picks (picks 1-30). Second-round picks can sign for any amount up to the maximum salary, often signing for minimum contracts or partial guarantees.

questions.question: If a first-round pick refuses to sign with the team that drafted them, what are the team's rights?
options: Exclusive rights until the next draft
Exclusive rights indefinitely until rights are renounced
questions.explanation: A team retains exclusive negotiating rights to a first-round pick indefinitely until they renounce those rights or trade them. The pick cannot sign elsewhere or re-enter the draft.

questions.question: What happens to Rookie Scale salaries when the salary cap increases significantly?
options: Existing contracts remain at original amounts
Contracts are automatically adjusted by cap percentage
questions.explanation: Rookie Scale Contracts are based on the cap at the time of signing. If the cap increases dramatically (like it did in 2016), players already under contract do not receive adjustments.

questions.question: Can a player decline their fourth-year team option to become a free agent early?
options: No, only the team can decline the option
questions.explanation: The third and fourth-year options are TEAM options only. The player has no ability to decline them. Only the team decides whether to exercise or decline each option.

questions.question: For Rookie Scale extension eligibility, does playing time in the third year matter?
options: Yes, must average 15+ minutes per game
No, just must complete the third season
Yes, must not be injured for more than 30 days
questions.explanation: Extension eligibility is based solely on completing the third season, not on games played or performance. Even injured players or those who barely played can sign extensions after year three.
